articles.headline: Uber Adds a Billion Dollars More to Its Coffers
articles.snippet: The private car service closed a new $1.2 billion round of financing, with investors valuing it at a staggering $40 billion.
articles.abstract: The private car service closed a new $1.2 billion round of financing, with investors valuing it at a staggering $40 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: Uber wants to be the world’s private driving service. Now the company is amassing the war chest to do it.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Cleveland Police Cited for Abuse by Justice Department
articles.snippet: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said a civil rights investigation had found “unreasonable and unnecessary use of force” by the department.
articles.abstract: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said a civil rights investigation had found “unreasonable and unnecessary use of force” by the department.
articles.lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — The Justice Department announced on Thursday that a nearly two-year civil rights investigation into the Cleveland Police Department had found a pattern of “unreasonable and unnecessary use of force” that resulted in dangerous and reckless behavior by officers, pointing out the kinds of problems that have angered black residents here and touched off demonstrations across the country in recent weeks.

articles.headline: Under ISIS Fire, Love Conquers
articles.snippet: A young couple on opposite sides of enemy lines in the town of Dhuluiya pulled off a daring plot to marry.
articles.abstract: A young couple on opposite sides of enemy lines in the town of Dhuluiya pulled off a daring plot to marry.
articles.lead_paragraph: DHULUIYA, Iraq — When Ekhlas Mohammed became engaged to a soft-spoken Iraqi soldier from the other side of town in Dhuluiya, she dreamed of the day she would wear a white dress and celebrate with friends, family, music and food.

articles.headline: Shake-Up at The New Republic: Franklin Foer and Leon Wieseltier Are Out
articles.snippet: Gabriel Snyder will replace Mr. Foer as the editor of the political magazine, which just celebrated its 100th anniversary.
articles.abstract: Gabriel Snyder will replace Mr. Foer as the editor of the political magazine, which just celebrated its 100th anniversary.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Guy Vidra joined The New Republic magazine in October as its chief executive, he gathered the staff around a conference table in its Washington offices overlooking the National Portrait Gallery.

articles.headline: A Strategy for Pensions at Risk of Extinction
articles.snippet: Multiemployer pension plans, often involving unionized workers, were once common in industries like coal mining, trucking and construction. But they’re running out of money.
articles.abstract: Multiemployer pension plans, often involving unionized workers, were once common in industries like coal mining, trucking and construction. But they’re running out of money.
articles.lead_paragraph: When people are old, should governments guarantee they have incomes?

articles.headline: Starbucks, Facing a Saturated Market, Looks to the High End
articles.snippet: Starbucks is planning a chain that will sell high-end coffee from around the world, and its branding will be steps removed from its mass-market cousin.
articles.abstract: Starbucks is planning a chain that will sell high-end coffee from around the world, and its branding will be steps removed from its mass-market cousin.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — It’s hard to believe that this coffee-crazed city would get excited about yet another coffee shop, particularly another Starbucks.

articles.headline: In Louisiana Runoff Election, Senator Landrieu Tries to Revive Her Base
articles.snippet: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, seeking a fourth term, faces a tough battle to rally her African-American supporters in a state where voters seem to be favoring Republicans.
articles.abstract: Senator Mary L. Landrieu, seeking a fourth term, faces a tough battle to rally her African-American supporters in a state where voters seem to be favoring Republicans.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAMMOND, La. — She has been rebuffed by her liberal colleagues in Washington and pilloried at home for voting with the president, and has watched helplessly while her Democratic base has eroded like a cheap levee.

articles.headline: Big Job Gains and Rising Pay in Labor Data
articles.snippet: The gain was the largest monthly jump in payrolls in nearly three years, and average hourly earnings surged 0.4 percent, twice what analysts expected.
articles.abstract: The gain was the largest monthly jump in payrolls in nearly three years, and average hourly earnings surged 0.4 percent, twice what analysts expected.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since the recovery from the Great Recession began more than five years ago, the most crucial missing pieces of the economic puzzle were the lack of consistently strong gains in hiring and better wages for most working Americans struggling to make ends meet. Now, at last, those pieces are starting to fall into place.

articles.headline: Steep Slide in Oil Prices Is Blessing for Most
articles.snippet: If history is any guide, it’s hard to see falling oil prices as anything but good news for everyone whose fortunes aren’t tied to oil.
articles.abstract: If history is any guide, it’s hard to see falling oil prices as anything but good news for everyone whose fortunes aren’t tied to oil.
articles.lead_paragraph: The plunge in oil prices — to about $66 a barrel from over $107 in late June — has many pundits wringing their hands. They have cited the risks of falling prices and social and political unrest overseas, not to mention the economic threat to the booming mid-American oil basin, running from Texas to North Dakota and Alberta.
